articles.headline: A Service to Pay Off High-Interest Credit Cards, but a Bad Time to Start
articles.snippet: The service, Tally, is starting its business at the same time that a similar lender, Lending Club, is in deep trouble with regulators and financiers.
articles.abstract: The service, Tally, is starting its business at the same time that a similar lender, Lending Club, is in deep trouble with regulators and financiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The promise that a new service called Tally makes to people with credit card debt is simple enough: Its app scans a picture of your cards, and you agree to a credit check. Then, let Tally pay off your high-interest cards using a new line of credit with a lower rate.

articles.headline: Republicans Want Their Party to Unify Behind Donald Trump, Poll Shows
articles.snippet: Even with the desire for unity, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows extraordinarily high levels of unpopularity for both Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: Even with the desire for unity, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows extraordinarily high levels of unpopularity for both Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: An overwhelming majority of Republican voters say their party’s leaders should get behind Donald J. Trump, even as he enters the general election saddled with toxic favorability ratings among the broader electorate, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Dalia Sussman

articles.headline: Walmart Outperforms Estimates, but Online Retail Lags
articles.snippet: Walmart reported Thursday that quarterly revenue rose 0.9 percent, signaling that its strategies to combat a dismal retail environment were working.
articles.abstract: Walmart reported Thursday that quarterly revenue rose 0.9 percent, signaling that its strategies to combat a dismal retail environment were working.
articles.lead_paragraph: One percent growth may not seem like a lot — unless you’re the world’s largest retailer.

articles.headline: ‘The Founder,’ Like Ray Kroc, Feasts on McDonald’s Imagery
articles.snippet: The movie uses McDonald’s well-guarded iconography for a bold visual tour of the chain’s early days, but treads lightly in its promotional material.
articles.abstract: The movie uses McDonald’s well-guarded iconography for a bold visual tour of the chain’s early days, but treads lightly in its promotional material.

articles.headline: EgyptAir Crash Blindsides a Nation That Thought It Was Recovering
articles.snippet: For years, Egypt has been hit with crisis after crisis, devastating its economic lifeblood, tourism. But recently, there had been signs of a turnaround.
articles.abstract: For years, Egypt has been hit with crisis after crisis, devastating its economic lifeblood, tourism. But recently, there had been signs of a turnaround.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt seemed poised for a modest comeback. After years of cascading crises that had devastated the lifeblood of its economy, tourism, there were signs of a turnaround.

articles.headline: Rancor Over Pipeline Merger Extends to Law Firms
articles.snippet: A lawsuit by Energy Transfer accusing Williams Companies of dawdling to avoid closing a deal reveals a battle among big-name Wall Street firms.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit by Energy Transfer accusing Williams Companies of dawdling to avoid closing a deal reveals a battle among big-name Wall Street firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: With no other options, Energy Transfer Equity needs to run down the clock.

articles.headline: Data Points to Rapid Loss of Control Aboard EgyptAir Jet
articles.snippet: Sensor data made public by a respected aviation journal indicates rapid and escalating failures in the plane’s flight control system.
articles.abstract: Sensor data made public by a respected aviation journal indicates rapid and escalating failures in the plane’s flight control system.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A piece of luggage adrift in the Mediterranean Sea. Floating nearby, a passenger seat from a plane. Scraps of metal, scattered personal belongings and, finally, the grim discovery of human remains.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim, Marc Santora and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: ‘Brexit,’ a Feel-Good Vote That Could Sink Britain’s Economy
articles.snippet: In their desire to leave the E.U., many Britons have found an outlet for fears about immigration and terrorism. But the cost of an exit would be high.
articles.abstract: In their desire to leave the E.U., many Britons have found an outlet for fears about immigration and terrorism. But the cost of an exit would be high.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — If not for the trifling matter of Britain potentially abandoning the European Union, Rowan Crozier figures the factory he oversees would already be clattering away with extra urgency. Men and women in blue coveralls would be busy patrolling the concrete floor, monitoring molded hunks of steel that stamp loops of metal into electronics parts. A new order would be destined for a major customer.

articles.headline: Fannie, Freddie and the Secrets of a Bailout With No Exit
articles.snippet: Newly unsealed documents cast doubt on the Treasury’s justification for sweeping the mortgage giants’ profits, exposing the perils of letting the government act in secret.
articles.abstract: Newly unsealed documents cast doubt on the Treasury’s justification for sweeping the mortgage giants’ profits, exposing the perils of letting the government act in secret.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Washington took over the beleaguered mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac during the collapse of the housing market and the financial crisis of 2008, it was with the implicit promise that they would be returned to shareholders after being nursed back to health.
